(and bank-like entities) issue them at scale

children.value: : Deposits are directly usable for transfers and settlements.

children.html: →\to→

children.value: Deposits are not just cheap funding, they are the
core of money, payments, and stability
Example: euro area banks in 2022 relied on
: Deposit rates typically below wholesale funding rates

children.html: →\to→

children.value: key driver of net interest margin (BIS, 2022).
: Retail deposits are more “sticky” than wholesale markets, providing resilience in crises (Gatev & Strahan, 2006).
: Banks with larger deposit bases were more stable in 2008 vs. wholesale-funded banks (Huang & Ratnovski, 2011).
: Deposits are the dominant form of broad money.
85% of the total stock of money
in the economy consists of bank deposits (ECB, Statistical Data Warehouse, 2023)
: Deposits are the medium of most electronic payments and transfers.
: Deposit and lending rates are the key channels for central bank rate changes (Bernanke & Blinder, 1992).
: Deposit runs have repeatedly triggered systemic crises (Calomiris & Gorton, 1991; Shin, 2009; Federal Reserve Board, 2023 on SVB).
introduced a simple model of deposit contracts.
: Because depositors don’t know when they’ll need money, banks provide an insurance: anyone can withdraw on demand.
Drawback: if depositors expect others to withdraw, they will rush to withdraw too

children.html: →\to→

children.value: Bank runs cause real economic damage because banks are forced to sell assets early at a loss.
It gave economists and policymakers a formal model showing that bank runs are not just random accidents, but a natural outcome of how banks work.
It shaped modern banking regulation and is one of the main reasons almost all countries insure deposits today.
Markets alone can’t insure this (information is private).
and offer a simple contract (demand deposits) that beats autarky/exchange.

private liquidity shocks and improve risk sharing.
How to mitigate the cost while enabling the value proprosition?
: Use information policy to anchor beliefs

children.html: f^\hat ff^​

children.value: : Transparent disclosure of solvency, liquidity, and guarantees.
: Low-cost if credible; can prevent panic without direct intervention.
: Credibility is fragile — if information is delayed, partial, or mistrusted, it may backfire.
: Central bank announcements during 2008 and 2023 crises (e.g., Fed’s joint statement on SVB deposit guarantees).
: Temporarily freeze withdrawals, forcing all depositors to wait.

children.html: fff
f^\hat ff^​
→\to→

children.value: disrupts payments, destroys trust, can trigger broader panic.
: 19th century U.S. banks and Argentina’s “corralito” in 2001.
: Central bank provides emergency liquidity when banks face sudden outflows.
, the central bank substitutes for deposits that run away.
: Stabilizes funding without guaranteeing all deposits.
: Risk of lending to insolvent banks (“bailouts”); stigma can deter use.
: Bank of England in 19th century (“Bagehot’s rule” — lend freely, against good collateral, at a penalty rate).
: Government (or guarantee scheme) promises to repay depositors even if the bank fails.
Eligibility for such insurance is the definition of banking
: Eliminates the late-type incentive to withdraw early

children.html: →\to→

children.value: : Restores depositor confidence; cornerstone of modern banking systems.
— banks and depositors may take more risk knowing deposits are guaranteed.
: FDIC created in the U.S. in 1933 after widespread bank runs.
5. Beyond Banks: Shadow Banking and Runs

children.label: 5. Beyond Banks: Shadow Banking and Runs

children.value: Financial institutions outside traditional banking system.
Examples: money market funds, structured investment vehicles (SIVs), repo dealers, stablecoin issuers.
(shares, repo contracts, tokens) that function like deposits:
Backed by longer-term or opaque assets
Same liquidity mismatch: short-term liabilities vs long-term assets.
Policy gap: when runs occur, systemic risk can spread through the financial system.
Banks fund them (e.g., repo, credit lines).
Banks hold their liabilities (e.g., money market fund shares).
Runs in shadow banking can therefore destabilize banks.
Run on money market funds (Reserve Primary Fund “broke the buck”).
Repo market freeze amplified bank funding crisis.
Deposit services are the reason banks are regulated.

children.html: →\to→
f^\hat ff^​

children.value: : intervention window collapses; communications policy is pivotal.
Same logic: liquidity mismatch + unverifiable backing

children.value: FX expectations interact with run risk (e.g., fear of devaluation).
Policy levers include convertibility limits and capital controls (costly).
